forumNotes.author: MR Cracker
forumNotes.content:
Hi  
I want to install [Universal XP](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=23553 "External link") in my flash memory and I have some questions  
1- I want to [Slipstream SP3](http://www.helpwithwindows.com/WindowsXP/Slipstreaming_Windows_XP_Service_Pack_3.html "External link")then add addones to it with [RyanVM Integrator 1.6](http://integrator.siginetsoftware.com/index.php?download "External link") and finally add Chipset, Mass Storage, CPU and LAN DriverPack to Source with [DriverPacks](http://driverpacks.net/downloads "External link"). is this right order?  
2- fast booting and portability are most important issues for me, can I be sure my Universal XP has this abilities?  
3- can I find a better why like LiveXp, BartPE, ect for XP booting?(fast booting, portability, power not portable apps)  
4- recently I have found that I can boot ISO images immediately with removeing --mem option is map command of grub is this change anything in qestion 3 about projects that can't run from usb?  

please answer to each qestion you khow.  
Thanks for help.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
You seem like not having fully grasped the idea of the "Universal XP".  
It is not actually as much a "universal XP" as it is a "learning XP".  
I.e. it will "learn" new hardware each time you boot it on new, different hardware.  
As such it will tend to "grow" in size.  
No problems that I know of by slipstreaming SP3, and RyanVM, all you will have at the end of them will be an updated source.  
Once you have the updated source, it's all right to add drivers, via DriverPacks or otherways.  

But if you are looking for fast booting it is not IMHO the best choice.  
It all depends on WHAT is the use of such a build, on a "full XP" (universal of not) you have heaps of bloatware that you will probably never use and that add to size and - even if not directly - to boot times (with new ditrect mapping features this has been reduced as the thingy is not anymore loadeed in RAM)  

A PE is more limited but usually smaller (please read as faster booting), additionally nothing prevents you (both with XP and with a PE) to divide the build in a very small "core" and have all the rest in another image and using junction points if needed or simply having all the apps in the other mounted image.  

The option of booting a .iso through grub4dos without --mem mapping has been an option since the very first releases, the only rquirement is that the .iso is contiguous.  

But still it won't work for a PE .iso (or for a .img) without some dedicated virtual disk driver added to the build (firadisk or winvblock) or using the now "old" ramdisk.sys form Windows 2003 SP! approach.  

Compare with:  
<http://reboot.pro/8944/>  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Wonko

> map --hook  
> chainloader (hd32)  
> boot

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> How can I make my xp.img readonly? > > I know it can be ambitious, but if it's possible to make img readonly, I'll not have problem with this goal Well if it's read only, you won't be able to: * update it * install drivers to it "on the fly" However: I think you will have a lot of fun conjugating that project (or the methods to have a XP read only) with Wimb's one. ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif) In any case you will need a RAMDISK of some kind and you will be again facing the problem of size of the image/iso/whatever to the actual size of available RAM. Unless you reduce size dramatically (which means more efficient BUT less features) I doubt that such a build would boot in a less that 1 Gb machine (not very portable, but of course depends on the "level" of the PC's you will use it on). My personal view on the matter is that what you want to do: * is perfectly possible (with some limitations) * it is complex and definitely ambitious (expecially for a non-expert) * provides no real advantages over a well designed/built PE 1.x (much easier to create) * the need in a "recovery system" of "latest updates", and expecially security ones is negligible * the need in a "recovery" system of \*any\* bells and whistles is non-existant and only adds to complexity, size and ultimately to problems * the reasons for not going the PE way are not really justifying the extra effort and complexity I am sure that nonetheless the Community will try it's best to help you in achieveing your goal :smile:.
![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: Doodoo
forumNotes.content:
Sorry for the lack of details but I am a bit short of time so that will only be a quick answer with guidelines and pointers....  

> Yes it deletes itsself files but today I've used it and saw if I use KTD it will not delete driver files after install  
> but again I am not sure that windows can search and find subfolders for new drivers which driverpacks is extracted files  
You're correct, by default DriverPacks extracts all the available drivers, installs whichever ones are needed at time of install (assuming you have integrated DriverPacks with XP setup), and then deletes all the files. If you want to take advantage of all the drivers available and use them as a "library of drivers" post-install then you have to enable the KTD option.  
Now, to tell windows where to search for new drivers, you have to update the registry key DevicePath in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion. See more details [here](http://reboot.pro/9830/page__st__150__p__122897#entry122897 "").  

> as I said I want to make my xp.img readonly because I don't want to virus or other programs can change image so  
> How can I make my xp.img readonly?  
You have already figured it out, the easiest way to make an image read only is to use the EWF filter, but you also have the ability to commit changes at some point.  
Installing the EWF filter is quite simple (have a look [here](http://www.saunalahti.fi/pesonpa/projects/windows_embedded/windows_embedded.php "External link")), but you might as well use the [Wimb's latest tools](http://reboot.pro/9830/page__st__400__p__132389#entry132389 "") to create your XP image, and they will automatically enable the EWF filter if desired.

forumNotes.author: Sha0
forumNotes.content:
> and this is state of my files:  
>
> then I had copied files to my flash and booted it:  
> ...  
> what I should do now?  
> wait for mapping of a 720MB image??  
Examine the contiguity of the files on the flash disk that you are booting. The contiguity of the files on your **C:** drive has no relation to the contiguity on the flash.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> In my flash I can boot files but as I said I have to wait for mapping of 720MB iso image and this can easily take an hour  
> I should wait for it?  

If you insist on mapping to memory, yes (and in this case you DO NOT need the file to be contiguous).  
If you try mapping the image directly, no (and in this case the image MUST be contiguous).  

JFYI, and as general advice, it is meaningless to post a report of an EFFECT without posting WHAT EXACT commands/settings/whatever you are experimenting with.  
Review this:  
[http://homepages.tes...ard-litany.html](http://homepages.tesco.net/J.deBoynePollard/FGA/problem-report-standard-litany.html "External link")  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Wonko

finally I found the problem  
cause was NTFS Compresstion. as you see in last image of post #10 size of xp-1.img on disk is 832kb and this file is between other files of disk so if img wants to grow up it should be fragmented  
I had disabled Compresstion and after some defragmenting problem solved  
and now I have installed XP and EWF and DevPath.exe are working good but when I want to boot img from my usb I recive 7b stop message  
I just added Chipset + CPU + Lan + MassStorage drivers with DriverPacks  
and did not pressed F6 to Load Drivers  
also I ca't understand this steps in Source Preparation so I didn't do them  
> Supports the use of BTS DriverPacks located in OEM Folder on USB-Drive  
> [http://driverpacks.net/downloads](http://driverpacks.net/downloads "External link")  
> For Install of XP on a modern system with SATA Drives it is needed to use DPsBase.exe  
> for Integrating in your XPSOURCE BTS DriverPack Massstorage with TXT Mode Enabled.  
> In that case a lot of Extra RAID SCSI and SATA Drivers (about 120 extra) are Integrated which appear in the  
> XP Setup BootFolder $WIN_NT$.\~BT on Install-Drive and can prevent a lot of XP Install Boot Problems.  
> It will be useful to Add also Chipset, CPU and LAN DriverPack, which are small so that  
> the decompression at the beginning of GUI-mode of XP Setup does NOT take to much time.  
> Always first use RyanVM Integrator or nLite and then use DPsBase to Improve your XP-Source.  
> The program supplies a Customised presetup.cmd and changes the winnt.sif file for use of DriverPacks.  
>
> When you don't use nLite, you can copy the supplied $OEM$ folder to your XP Source folder.  
> Change $OEM$ folder to your needs for UserAccounts and Registry Tweaks and Adding Drivers.  
> CMDLINES.TXT is used for making UserAccounts and install of Registry Tweaks at T-12  
> Info see: [http://unattended.ms.../unattended.xp/](http://unattended.msfn.org/unattended.xp/ "External link")  
>
> PnP Drivers specified in winnt.sif can be added to $OEM$\\$1\\Drivers  
> [http://unattended.ms...xp/view/web/34/](http://unattended.msfn.org/unattended.xp/view/web/34/ "External link")  
> TEXTMODE Drivers defined in winnt.sif and located in $OEM$\\TEXTMODE folder of the XP Source  
> can be used instead of using F6 floppy for MassStorage Drivers.  
> The content of the $OEM$\\TEXTMODE folder is copied by USB_XP_Setup.exe to XP Setup BootFolder $WIN_NT$.\~BT\\$OEM$
![:good:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/good.gif)

forumNotes.author: Doodoo
forumNotes.content:
> and now I have installed XP and EWF and DevPath.exe are working good but when I want to boot img from my usb I recive 7b stop message  
If you use Wimb's tools, presumably the whole thing relies on WinVBlock, right ?  

In this case, there is a possibility that things don't work and you get a BSOD 7B. It may work on some hardware, and not on some other. This is a timing problem, as discussed at length in [this thread](http://reboot.pro/14130/ "").  
For now, the only workaround is to avoid booting from an IMG, and to boot from flat files instead. Also [a little driver by Shao](http://reboot.pro/14130/ "") is necessary. In other words if you extract all the files from the IMG and put them on your flash disk, it should be working (assuming basic requirements are met, like proper formatting, etc...). I believe Wimb's IMG_XP_Restore will do that job nicely for you and will also inject Shao's waitbt32.sys automatically.
